criteria: Ability to Use the Periodic Table
descriptions: No understanding of atomic structure is demonstrated.
Demonstrates minimal understanding of atomic structure (protons, neutrons, electrons).
Identifies the components of atomic structure but struggles to relate them to the periodic table.
Describes atomic structure and its relation to the number of protons in the nucleus, with some inaccuracies.
Accurately explains atomic structure and its direct relationship to the organization of elements in the periodic table.
Provides a comprehensive explanation of atomic structure and its role in determining an element's placement and properties within the periodic table.
Unable to locate elements on the periodic table or identify basic information.
Can locate elements but cannot extract meaningful information about their properties.
Identifies groups and periods but struggles to relate them to element properties.
Uses the periodic table to identify some trends in element properties (e.g., reactivity of metals) with limited accuracy.
Effectively uses the periodic table to predict trends in element properties, such as reactivity and bonding, with some minor errors.
Expertly uses the periodic table to accurately predict and explain trends in element properties, including reactivity, types of bonds formed, and numbers of bonds.
Unable to predict any element properties based on periodic table position.
Attempts to predict properties but demonstrates no understanding of the underlying principles.
Predicts basic properties (e.g., metal vs. nonmetal) with limited accuracy.
Predicts some properties based on group or period trends but struggles with more complex properties like bond types.
Predicts various properties, including reactivity and bond formation, with reasonable accuracy and justification.
Provides accurate and insightful predictions of element properties, supported by a thorough understanding of electron configuration and periodic trends.
Demonstrates no understanding of electron patterns or their significance.
Mentions electrons but does not connect them to element properties.
Identifies that elements in the same group have similar electron configurations, but cannot explain why.
Explains the relationship between electron configuration and group number with some inaccuracies.
Accurately explains how the patterns of electrons in the outermost energy level determine element properties.
Provides a detailed explanation of how electron configuration dictates chemical behavior and accurately relates it to element placement in the periodic table.
